ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Olympic history, ancient and modern, in the context of relevant contemporary topics
Reading complex accounts form Ancient Greece and analysis.
History of the Olympic Games and how external influences shaped how they are today

I improved my analytical skills in history a lot and learned about the history of the Olympics. I was not aware how much of a philosophy Olympism was, and how much scholarship there was behind it until this course.
I learned a lot about the history of the Olympic Games and Greece and how the past has influenced the contemporary Olympics.
I honed my critical writing skills.

This course taught me a lot about ancient Greece and the Olympics and how the modern Olympic movement emerged from ancient origins. I also learned about modern-day controversies and debates in the Olympics from the gender gap and sex testing to racism and the role of the media. Ultimately, this course helped to emphasize to me the intersections between sport and politics, economics, and social change from the ancient to modern Olympic Games.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Students were engaged and Professor was very communicative. He was more than happy to meet to discuss the class and assignments.
Really great discussion, Professor Syrimis was great at asking thought provoking questions and fostered a welcoming environment

The once-a-week format was a bit difficult because it condensed all the readings into a class that felt too short to cover everything. I would have preferred meeting twice a week for less time each day than once a week. The strengths, I would say, was the contact and Prof. Syrimis.
Great course!
This course was excellent. Professor Syrimis is wonderful and made all of the seminars really engaging.

Strengths: one of the only sports history courses at Yale; Professor Syrimis is very engaged and interested in the topics; study of change over time; provides a historical foundation for understanding current events and how we see the Olympics and what they mean to us and to athletes today.
Weaknesses: sometimes, class felt a bit disorganized and we would go off on tangents or get off topic easily, class could dissolve into just the professor talking to the athletes and not engaging everyone. I think having a clear agenda at the start would help to stay on topic or address overarching themes at the beginning so we can follow along.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was as good as a virtual seminar could get

Everything was good, except I wish we had done more work in breakout rooms or something of the sort. The class could feel isolating at time since there were little/no events for us to meet each other.
N/A

Seminar was fully virtual but we were still learning, participating, and engaged in the class. Didn't feel like a lot was done to transition to virtual learning but still worked fine, besides the fact that we used the "Raise Hand" function on zoom to help with participation.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Easy but interesting. Just weekly discussion posts up until the midterm paper! The assignments give you a lot of leeway to focus on topics you're interested in/knowledgeable about.
Yes! Great professor, great content. Especially recommend to athletes
Yes, if you want to increase your capacity for analysis and learn to look at readings and history in a different way.
Yes, if you are interested in the history of the Olympics and want to learn about ancient Greece
I would definitely recommend this course to another student. Class discussions are dynamic and interesting and you learn a lot about ancient Greece and the Olympic Games.

Yes! If you're interested in the Olympics or sports history more generally, then I would definitely recommend taking this course. Or if you're an athlete or just love sports, then this may be the class for you. Even if you're not an athlete, this is also a really interesting course to understand the predominant role sports plays in our culture today and since ancient times.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual office hours
just the weekly seminar over zoom and office hour sessions
N/A
